contentrichtext.text: Judge '''Donald E. Belfi''', born January 21, 1936, was a [[lawyer]] and [[politician]] in [[Nassau County, New York]]. In 1994, he presided over the trial of [[Long Island Rail Road]] shooter [[Colin Ferguson (convict)|Colin Ferguson]].<ref name="pview.findlaw.com">[http://pview.findlaw.com/view/1468412_1?noconfirm=0 'Donald E. Belfi', ''FindLaw Lawyer Directory'' (15 March 2006]. Retrieved 29 April 2006.</ref> ==Early life== Born in 1936 in [[Brooklyn, New York]], Belfi gained his [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in [[English language|English]] from [[Georgetown University]] in 1957 and [[Doctor of Jurisprudence]] from [[Fordham University]] School of Law in 1960.<ref name="pview.findlaw.com"/> At Fordham, he was selected by New York County District Attorney [[Frank Hogan]] to join his office upon graduation, as part of the Honor's Program.<ref name="pview.findlaw.com"/> ==Career== From 1960 to 1962, he served as an [[Assistant District Attorney]] in [[Manhattan]], and from 1962 to 1974 he served as an Assistant District Attorney in Nassau County. In 1975, he was elected to the Nassau County [[New York Supreme Court|District Court]] bench on the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] and Conservative tickets. He was re-elected in 1980 on the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]], Republican, [[Conservative Party of New York|Conservative]], and [[Liberal Party of New York|Liberal]] tickets. He was elected to the [[County Court]] of Nassau County in 1984, re-elected in 1994, and ran unsuccessfully for re-election in 2004 on the Republican and Conservative tickets. After leaving public service Belfi joined the Manhattan practice of [[Murray, Frank & Sailer LLP]] as senior counsel.<ref name="pview.findlaw.com"/> At his retirement from the bench on 14 February 2005, [[Carolyn McCarthy]] paid tribute to him in the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]]. McCarthy's husband and son were both shot by Ferguson in 1994. His voluntary activities included serving as commissioner of [[Rockville Centre, New York|Rockville Centre]] [[Little League]], and as a member of the [[Knights of Columbus]], the [[Association for the Help of Retarded Children]], and the [[St. Agnes Cathedral]] Parish Council. He also contributed over 20 years to Georgetown University as both an interviewer and a recruiter for the school. His honors included the [[Fraternal Order of Court Officers]] Bench and Bar Award, the [[Criminal Courts Bar Association]]'s [[Norman F. Lent]] Award, the Fordham Law Alumni Association Distinguished Alumnus Award, the [[DeStefano Industries]]Annual Award, and the Court Officer's Benevolent Association of Nassau County Fidelis Juris Award.<ref>[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?r109:E14FE5-0003: Carolyn McCarthy, 'Tribute to the Honorable Donald E. Belfi', ''Congressional Record'' (14 February 2005].
